Recent contributions include donating robotic deer to government for poacher conviction, winter deer browse cutting programs, extensive nest box placement throughout region. post_address: E.T. Seton Park, Don Mills Road south of Eglinton
post_content: Toronto's only public outdoor archery range, one of only two public archery ranges in Canada. Bequeathed to the City of Toronto by Ernest Thompson Seton (1860-1946), Scottish-Canadian author, wildlife artist, naturalist, self-trained biologist, and founding member of Boy Scouts of America. Seton donated the land with stipulation it remain free and open to public 24/7, 365 days per year forever. Field transformed to archery range in 1968 following petition signed by 800 people. FREE ADMISSION, NO PERMITS REQUIRED. Open 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, year-round. No supervision - operates on honour system with posted rules and regulations. Maintained by City of Toronto Parks staff on as-needed basis. Range size: equivalent of two football fields. Shooting distances available from 18 metres to 70 metres. Used by complete beginners to Olympic-level athletes. Bring your own equipment - no equipment provided or available for rent. Located in E.T. Seton Park, part of chain of parks forming forested corridor for hiking along Don River. Closest entrance off Thorncliffe Park Drive just south of Overlea Boulevard (runs between Don Mills Road and Laird). Drive-in entrance closes annually at first snowfall, reopens when snow melts in spring. Closest transit: Don Mills Road at Gateway Boulevard stop (south end of Ontario Science Centre), walk down paved roadway to range on left. Park also features: 18-hole disc golf course (installed 2011), jogging and cycling paths, Nordic skiing trails, equestrian trails, three fire pits. Wildlife viewing opportunities: red squirrels, eagles, deer, songbirds. Listed as top birdwatching spot in City's Birds of Toronto Biodiversity Series booklet. Listed in Toronto's 2015 Pan American Games bid book as archery location but not used due to vehicle access limitations. Park named after E.T. Seton, who emigrated from England to Toronto in 1866 at age 6. Wrote 60 books and nearly 400 magazine articles/stories including Wild Animals I Have Known and Boy Scout Handbook. Passionate about promoting archery throughout his life.
